markscheme-components.a.i: Positive correlation (1 mark: 1 AO1.1). Condone “positive” or correct description (for example: “As the temperature increases, more ice creams are sold.”)
markscheme-components.a.ii: Correct reason, for example: “He sold far more ice creams than you would expect him to for a 20°C day.” (1 mark: 1 AO2.3a)
markscheme-components.b.iii: The (b)(i) prediction is more reliable, as it is within the range of the given data (2 marks: 1 AO2.1b, 1 AO2.4a). B1 for (b)(i) prediction identified with partial reason.
markscheme-components.c: No, because there may be other factors involved (2 marks: 1 AO2.5a, 1 AO3.4b). B1 for “No,” with partial reason.

markscheme-components.b:

• 3 AO2.2

  (Implied by 36 450 and 32 805)
OR

  (Implied by 40 500)
markscheme-components.c:
(c) Answer: 8[%] with correct working (5 marks)

• 3 AO1.3b
• 2 AO3.1d

Marking instructions:

– B4 for answer 108[%] or 1.08 or [0].08 with correct working
  OR
– M3 for 1.2 × [0].9 (oe)
  or for (100 000 × 1.2 × [0].9 – 100 000) ÷ 100 000
  OR
– M2 for 1.2 and [0].9
  OR
– M1 for 1.2 or [0].9

If 0 or 1 mark is scored, instead award SC2 for answer 8[%] with no working or insufficient working.

If 0 marks are scored, instead award SC1 for 108[%] or 1.08 or [0].08 with no working or insufficient working.

“Correct working” requires evidence of at least M3 or an alternative convincing approach.

Throughout, percentage calculations may be performed in stages, e.g. 120% by adding 20%.

Examples:
• 100 000 × 1.2 × [0].9
• 120 000 × [0].9
• 100 000 × 1.2 implied by 120 000

markscheme-components.a:
Part (a):

The first error is in step 2 — because −3x − 2x = −5x, not −x, as given.

Marks: 2 (2 AO2.5a)
• B1 for identifying step 2
• B1 for explaining the error
markscheme-components.b:
Part (b):

[x² + 4x + x + 4 = x² − 3x − 2x + 6]
x² + 5x + 4 = x² − 5x + 6
5x + 4 = −5x + 6
10x + 4 = 6
10x = 2
x = 1/5

Marks: 2 (2 AO1.3a)
• M1 for an attempt to correct the solution in line with their answer to (a)
